section.title: Creating and Deploying a JSF Portlet
section.para: This chapter will explain how you can configure a JSF portlet within a JSF project with JBoss Portlet capabilities and then deploy it to JBoss Portal.

section.title: Creating a JSF Project with JBoss Portlet Capabilities
section.para: You can create a JSF project with JBoss Portlet capabilities in two ways:

listitem.para: Create a dynamic Web project with the JavaServer Faces and JBoss JSF Portlet facets enabled (see )
Or create a JSF project using the wizard provided by JBoss JSF Tools, then enable JSF and JBoss Portlet facets and add JBoss Portlet capabilities (see )

section.para: Refer to the further sections for the procedures on how to do this.

section.title: Creating a Dynamic Web Project with the JBoss Portlet Capabilities
section.para: The basic steps to create a dynamic Web project with the JBoss Portlet capabilities are as follows:

listitem.para: Start the Dynamic Web Project wizard navigating to FileNewOtherWebDynamic Web Project.

note.title: Tip:
note.para: You can also select the Java EE perspective and then selecting FileNewDynamic Web Project.

listitem.para: Specify the project name and set the target runtime to JBoss Portal by following the points 3, 4 and 5 in the procedure.
In the Configurationarea, click the Modify button and enable JavaServer Faces,JBoss Core Portlet and JBoss JSF Portlet facets. Click the OK button.
You may leave the next two wizard pages with their defaults, just press the Next button to proceed.
On the JBoss Portlet Capabilities page, select Portlet Target Runtime Provider and click the Next button.

note.title: Tip:
note.para: All types of the portlet implementation library are described more closely in the wiki article at: http://www.jboss.org/community/wiki/PortletFacetLibraries.

listitem.para: Next wizard page is for configuring JSF capabilities. You can leave everything as it is here.

On the JBoss JSF Portlet Capabilities page, select JSF Portlet Target Runtime Provider as the JSF portlet implementation library. It will copy Portlet Bridge libraries from the server runtime to the project classpath.

note.title: Tip:
note.para: On this page, it is also possible to add the RichFaces libraries from the RichFaces distribution by checkingAdd/Change Richfaces Libraries.

note.title: Note:
note.para: You can select the JSF Portletbridge Runtime Provider type. Then it is necessary to set the home of the Portlet Bridge distribution.
For information about all the JSF Portlet facet library providers, refer to the wiki article at: http://community.jboss.org/wiki/PortletFacetLibraries.

listitem.para: Click the Finish button. The project will be created in the workbench.

section.title: Creating a JSF Project and adding the JBoss Portlet Capabilities
section.para: For information on how to organize a JSF project you can read the JSF Tools User Guide. Just remember to point the target runtime to JBoss Portal directory location (see how it is done for a dynamic Web project with steps 3, 4 and 5 in the procedure).
To add the JBoss Portlet capabilities to the JSF project you should complete the next steps:

listitem.para: Right-click the project and click Properties to open the project Properties sheet. Select Project Facets on the left and enable the JavaServer Faces, JBoss Core Portlet and JBoss JSF Portlet facets.

Notice that the "Further configuration available..." warning appears at the bottom of the screen. It means that next you should configure the JSF Portlet capabilities in the project. Click the link. The Modify Faceted Project wizard appears.
Complete all wizard pages the same way as described in the steps 5, 6, 7 of the procedure. Click the OK button.
To apply the changes click the Apply button and then the OK button to close the project Properties sheet.

section.title: Adding a JSF Portlet to the Project and Deploying It to JBoss Portal
section.para: The previous section demonstrated how to create a JSF project with JBoss Portlet and JSF Portlet capabilities enabled. Use the following procedure to add a JSF portlet to the created project and deploy it to JBoss Portal.

listitem.para: Display the Create Portlet wizard by selecting NewOtherJBoss Tools WebPortletJSF/Seam Portlet from the context menu of the project (for information about the wizard options, see in the guide reference).

note.title: Tip:
note.para: As you see, the JSF and Seam Portlet wizards are merged into one. We have set the JSF configuration for the project, so the default values in this wizard will be set as for a JSF portlet.

listitem.para: Leave all the wizard pages with default values by clicking the Next button, on the last one click the Finish button to complete the JSF portlet creation.
Complete the steps described in the procedure to deploy a JSF portlet to JBoss Portal. Just use the other URL to see it in the browser: http://localhost:8080/portal/portal/default/JSFPortlet.
